conflictDescription: User Story A wants the system to allow quick access to patient data by caregivers in emergencies or with consent, while User Story B wants to restrict caregiver options and force workflows even if caregivers do not want it. This creates opposite instructions on caregiver access and freedom of action.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly with consent or in emergencies, so I can make fast clinical decisions.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to restrict caregiver options to keep control and force workflows even if caregivers do not want it.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to balance quick access for caregivers during emergencies or with consent, and controlled workflows to ensure security and proper procedure.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want quick access to patient data with consent or emergencies, so I can make fast and safe decisions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to enforce controlled caregiver workflows with flexibility for emergency access, to keep security and usability balanced.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to allow quick access to patient data with consent or in emergencies, while User Story B wants to force users to share data even if they do not want to. These are opposite expectations on data sharing and consent enforcement.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly with consent or in emergencies, so I can make fast clinical decisions.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to push users to share health data and accept updates even if they do not want to, so data collection is complete and apps stay current.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to respect user consent while allowing emergency data access, balancing privacy and data completeness.
newUserStoryASummary: As a nurse, I want to access patient data quickly with consent or during emergencies, so I can make fast clinical decisions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to encourage users to share health data and accept updates while respecting their consent, so data collection is reliable.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires accessing patient health data only with consent or in emergencies, while User Story B wants to forcibly install apps without user consent. These impose opposite expectations about consent requirements on system behavior.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly with consent or in emergencies, so I can make fast clinical decisions.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to forcibly install apps on users' devices, so that healthcare features are always present regardless of user consent.
resolutionDescription: Modify both stories to respect user consent by allowing health data access only with consent or emergencies, and permitting app installation only with user approval or in critical situations.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data only with user consent or emergencies, so I can make safe clinical decisions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to install apps on users' devices only with consent or in emergencies, so healthcare features are available without violating privacy.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires the system to allow access to patient health data with consent or in emergencies, while User Story B demands strict enforcement of notification delivery even if users do not want it, implying no override or consent bypass. These impose opposite expectations on system behavior regarding user consent and notification enforcement.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly with consent or in emergencies, so I can make fast clinical decisions.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to enforce strict notification delivery in ALFRED, even if users do not want to receive them.
generalResolutionType: 2. Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: User Story B is updated to allow notification delivery only with user consent or in emergencies, respecting privacy and consent while keeping User Story A unchanged.
newUserStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to access patient health data quickly with consent or in emergencies, so I can make fast clinical decisions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to enforce notification delivery only with user consent or in emergencies, so that privacy and user preferences are respected.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants the caregiver to have control over when health data is logged to protect privacy, but User Story B wants to restrict caregiver options and force workflows, even if caregivers do not want it. These are opposite instructions on caregiver control and system operation.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control when health data is logged, so I can protect privacy according to user wishes.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to restrict caregiver options to keep control and force workflows even if caregivers do not want it.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow caregiver control over health data logging with system-enforced privacy policies to balance control and workflow consistency.
newUserStoryASummary: As a caregiver, I want to control when health data is logged, so I can protect user privacy within system rules.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to enforce privacy policies while allowing caregiver control to maintain workflow and data security.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to control and limit health data logging to protect privacy, while User Story B wants to force users to share health data and accept updates even if they do not want to. These are opposite actions on the same event of data sharing.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control when health data is logged, so I can protect privacy according to user wishes.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to push users to share health data and accept updates even if they do not want to, so data collection is complete and apps stay current.
resolutionDescription: We clarify data sharing by allowing caregivers to control logging respecting user privacy, while developers encourage sharing data with clear consent and opt-in updates. This balances privacy and data completeness with user control.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control health data logging with user consent, so that privacy is protected.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to encourage users to share health data and accept updates with clear consent, so data is complete and apps stay current.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to control when health data is logged to protect privacy, while User Story B wants to forcibly install apps without user consent, which contradicts the control and privacy protection. These impose opposite system behaviors on user consent and control.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control when health data is logged, so I can protect privacy according to user wishes.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to forcibly install apps on users' devices, so that healthcare features are always present regardless of user consent.
generalResolutionType: Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: The developer's user story is updated to require user consent before installing apps, respecting privacy control by caregivers who manage health data logging.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control when health data is logged, so I can protect privacy according to user wishes.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to install healthcare apps only with user consent, so essential features are present without violating privacy.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to control and limit when health data is logged to protect privacy, while User Story B wants to enforce strict notification delivery even if users do not want them. This means one story wants to stop some actions based on user wishes, and the other wants to force actions regardless, which is a clear conflict.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control when health data is logged, so I can protect privacy according to user wishes.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to enforce strict notification delivery in ALFRED, even if users do not want to receive them.
resolutionDescription: Apply a contextual policy layer that respects user privacy by controlling health data logging, while ensuring critical notifications are delivered under specific conditions with user consent.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control when health data is logged, so that user privacy is protected following their wishes.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to enforce important notification delivery in ALFRED, respecting user consent except in urgent cases.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires urgent alerts only with client consent or emergencies, while User Story B wants to restrict caregiver options to force workflows even if caregivers do not want it, which can forbid respecting client consent. These demands oppose each other for the same event of urgent alerts.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive urgent alerts only with client consent or in emergencies, so I respect their privacy and help properly.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to restrict caregiver options to keep control and force workflows even if caregivers do not want it.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to include a context-aware policy layer that respects client consent while allowing caregivers to follow necessary workflows in emergencies, balancing privacy and control.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want urgent alerts only with client consent or emergencies, so I respect privacy and help properly.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to enforce caregiver workflows but allow exceptions for client consent and emergencies.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires that urgent alerts are sent only with client consent or in emergencies, while User Story B requires the system to push users to share data and accept updates even without consent, forcing actions against user will. These are opposite expectations on handling user consent.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive urgent alerts only with client consent or in emergencies, so I respect their privacy and help properly.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to push users to share health data and accept updates even if they do not want to, so data collection is complete and apps stay current.
resolutionDescription: The conflict is a Start-Forbid conflict about user consent for urgent alerts and data sharing. Both user stories are updated to respect user consent while allowing emergency exceptions and encourage data sharing with clear user permission requests.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive urgent alerts only with user consent or in emergencies, so I respect privacy and provide proper help.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to encourage users to share health data and accept updates with clear consent, to keep data complete and apps current.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires urgent alerts only with client consent or in emergencies, while User Story B wants to forcibly install apps without user consent. These impose opposite instructions about user consent for app installation and alerts, causing a direct contradiction.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive urgent alerts only with client consent or in emergencies, so I respect their privacy and help properly.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to forcibly install apps on users' devices, so that healthcare features are always present regardless of user consent.
resolutionDescription: Add context-aware conditions that respect user consent for alerts and allow app installation only with explicit permission or in emergencies, avoiding direct conflict.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive urgent alerts only with client consent or in emergencies, so I respect their privacy and help properly.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to install apps on users' devices only with user consent or in emergencies, so healthcare features are available without violating privacy.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires urgent alerts only with client consent or emergencies, while User Story B requires enforcing strict notification delivery even if users do not want them. This creates opposite expectations on alert delivery under the same conditions.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive urgent alerts only with client consent or in emergencies, so I respect their privacy and help properly.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to enforce strict notification delivery in ALFRED, even if users do not want to receive them.
resolutionDescription: Modify both stories to allow urgent alerts with user consent or in emergencies, while enabling strict notification delivery only in critical cases or with override policies.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive urgent alerts with client consent or in emergencies, so I respect their privacy and help properly.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to enforce strict notification delivery only in emergencies or with user consent override, so urgent alerts are always delivered when needed.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block non-emergency notifications during work hours (forbid operation), while User Story B wants to send notifications even if users refuse (start operation), which is contradictory for the same notification event.
userStoryASummary: As a registered nurse, I want to block all non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients and avoid distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
resolutionDescription: The conflict is resolved by clarifying notification types and user context: non-emergency notifications are blocked during work hours, but emergency notifications are always sent with override. This balances nurse focus and caregiver needs.
newUserStoryASummary: As a nurse, I want to block non-emergency notifications during work hours so I can focus on patients without distractions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send emergency notifications even if users refuse, so caregivers and patients get critical information.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to allow caregivers to control and possibly stop notifications for clients, while User Story B wants the system to always send notifications even if users refuse. This means one story says to stop notifications on user refusal and the other says to send them anyway, which is a direct contradiction.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control notifications for each client myself, so I can avoid overload and respect their wishes.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
resolutionDescription: The conflict is resolved by defining notification control with context-awareness: caregivers can manage non-critical notifications respecting user wishes, while critical notifications are always sent to ensure safety.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control non-critical notifications for clients, so I can avoid overload and respect their wishes.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to always send critical notifications, even if users refuse, so caregivers and patients get important information.

conflictDescription: User Story A expects notifications to be clear and manageable for caregivers, implying user consent or control, while User Story B requires forcing notifications even if users refuse, which forbids respecting user refusal. These are opposite expectations on notification control.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to see notifications for each client clearly, so I can care for them without getting mixed up or tired.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
resolutionDescription: Notifications will be sent respecting user consent unless there is a critical health alert, ensuring caregivers receive important info without ignoring user refusal.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to see clear notifications with user consent, so I can care well without overload.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send important notifications even if users refuse, only for critical alerts, so caregivers and patients get urgent info.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants the caregiver to choose which notifications to see first, implying control over notifications, while User Story B requires sending notifications to users even if they refuse, which forbids ignoring notifications. These are opposite instructions about allowing notification refusal.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to choose which client notifications to see first so I can handle my work without feeling too busy.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
resolutionDescription: The conflict is resolved by allowing caregivers to prioritize important notifications while ensuring critical alerts are always sent to users, balancing control and mandatory delivery.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to prioritize notifications by importance so I can manage my work without feeling too busy.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send critical notifications to users even if they refuse, so important information is always received.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants the caregiver to manually choose which alerts to acknowledge, meaning some alerts can be ignored. User Story B wants ALFRED to send notifications even if the user refuses, forcing alerts to be delivered. These two stories have opposite expectations on how notifications are handled.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to manually choose which alerts to acknowledge for each client, so I can control my responses and not miss important messages.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
resolutionDescription: We update both stories to allow caregivers to manually acknowledge alerts, but critical alerts are always sent by ALFRED regardless of refusal, balancing control and safety.
newUserStoryASummary: As a caregiver, I want to choose which alerts to acknowledge, so I can manage my responses carefully.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to always send critical notifications even if users refuse, so important information is not missed.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to control and avoid notifications during care tasks to prevent interruptions, while User Story B wants to send notifications even if users refuse them. These are opposite behaviors for the same event of sending notifications.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control when I get notifications during care tasks so I can focus on each client without interruptions.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
resolutionDescription: User Story A is updated to allow caregivers to set notification preferences during care tasks, and User Story B is updated to allow critical notifications to override refusal only in urgent cases. This creates a context-aware notification policy balancing user focus and information delivery.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to set notification preferences during care tasks so I can reduce interruptions but still get important alerts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send urgent notifications even if users refuse, so caregivers and patients receive critical information on time.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to allow caregivers to customize alert sounds, implying control over notifications, while User Story B requires the system to force notifications even if users refuse, which forbids user refusal and may override customization preferences.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to choose alert sounds for each client to quickly know who needs help without looking.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
resolutionDescription: Implemented a context-aware policy that allows caregivers to customize alert sounds but enforces critical notifications override only in emergency situations to ensure important info is always received.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to choose alert sounds for each client, so I quickly know who needs help without looking, except in emergencies.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send critical notifications even if users refuse, so caregivers and patients always get urgent information.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to allow manual control to stop urgent alerts to respect privacy, while User Story B wants to force sending notifications even if users refuse. These are opposite instructions about sending notifications triggered by urgent events.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to manually control urgent alerts for each client to respect their privacy and respond properly.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
generalResolutionType: 2. Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: Update User Story A to allow manual control over urgent alerts within privacy limits, while keeping User Story B to send critical notifications when no override is active, balancing privacy and safety.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control urgent alerts respecting privacy, so I can respond properly without blocking critical notifications.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications even if users refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to accept all notifications at night but allow choosing urgent ones, implying some notifications can be ignored. User Story B wants to force sending notifications even if users refuse them, which forbids ignoring notifications. These oppose each other on handling notifications during night.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to accept all notifications at night but choose which are urgent, so I can stay responsive without missing important alerts.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
resolutionDescription: Notifications at night are allowed with user choice for urgency, but critical notifications are always sent to ensure important alerts are not missed.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to accept all notifications at night but choose urgent ones, so I stay responsive without missing important alerts.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to always send critical notifications, even if users refuse, so caregivers and patients get vital information.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants ALFRED to show urgent needs clearly, implying notifications should be visible and focused. User Story B wants ALFRED to send notifications even if users refuse, forcing notifications. These impose opposite expectations on notification behavior under refusal conditions.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver managing many clients, I want ALFRED to show urgent needs clearly so I can act fast without losing focus.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
generalResolutionType: 2. Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: User Story B is updated to send only critical notifications despite refusal, respecting user choice while ensuring urgent info reach caregivers. User Story A remains to focus on clear urgent needs presentation.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to show urgent needs clearly so I can act fast without losing focus.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send critical notifications even if users refuse, so caregivers always get important information.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to stop notifications at certain times to avoid disturbance, while User Story B wants to send notifications even if the user refuses. These are opposite instructions for notification sending under the same event of user refusal.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to follow clients' wishes for interaction times, so I do not disturb their daily routine.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
resolutionDescription: We update both stories to balance user preferences and critical notifications by allowing notifications to be paused during preferred times but always sending urgent notifications.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to respect clients' preferred times for notifications, so I do not disturb their daily routine unnecessarily.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send urgent notifications even during quiet times, so caregivers and patients receive critical information promptly.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to control and limit when clients send social invitations (forbid notifications at some times), while User Story B wants to force notifications to be sent even if users refuse. These are opposite instructions about sending notifications under the same condition.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control when clients send social invitations, so I can manage my time and avoid feeling too busy.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
generalResolutionType: 2. Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: Allow caregivers to control notification times while ensuring critical notifications are sent with priority overrides in emergencies.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to control when social invitations notify users, so I can manage my time and avoid overload.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send critical notifications even if users refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to receive all notifications without restriction, while User Story B demands sending notifications even if users refuse, which is opposite to respecting user refusal. This is a conflict because one expects notifications only with consent, and the other forces notifications ignoring refusal.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive all notifications, including health updates and emotional prompts, so I can support my clients well.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications to users even if they refuse, so caregivers and patients always get important information.
generalResolutionType: 2. Update one and keep one remain the same
resolutionDescription: Update the developer's user story to respect user consent while keeping the caregiver's need for notifications, ensuring notifications are sent only with user permission.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to receive all notifications, including health updates and emotional prompts, so I can support my clients well.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to send notifications only with user consent, so caregivers and patients receive important information respectfully.
